questions.text: A 20-year-old male came with redness, photophobia, and foreign body sensation for a day. Examination findings are as shown below. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a corneal foreign body, and the next appropriate step is removal using a 25-G needle under slit-lamp guidance.

  • A superficial corneal foreign body presents with foreign body sensation, photophobia, and redness. Once the foreign body is visualised, a slit lamp should be used to determine its depth and exact position, followed by careful removal using a sterile hypodermic needle, commonly 25 gauge.

Explanation of other options:

Starting antibiotics (Option A): It is important after the removal to prevent secondary infection, but not the initial step if the foreign body is still embedded.

Removal under microscope in OT (Option B): It is invasive and reserved for deeper or intraocular cases.

Liberal wash (Option C) may help in cases of loose particles or chemical exposure, but is ineffective and unsafe for embedded corneal foreign bodies, especially metallic or plant-based ones.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man complains of difficulty in reading the newspaper with his right eye, three weeks after sustaining a gunshot injury to his left eye. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis is sympathetic ophthalmitis, which typically follows penetrating ocular trauma in the opposite eye.

  • Sympathetic ophthalmitis (SO) is an autoimmune-mediated bilateral panuveitis triggered by penetrating trauma or, less commonly, intraocular surgery. It is marked by a history of penetrating trauma in the exciting eye and the development of symptoms in the contralateral (sympathising) eye, usually around 2 weeks - 3 months later. It occurs due to exposure to the uveal antigens released from the injured eye.
  • The condition manifests with blurred vision, photophobia, pain, and loss of accommodation, most prominently in the symptomatic eye. Clinical findings include anterior uveitis, vitritis, and multifocal choroiditis.
  • Dalen Fuchs nodules are granulomas situated between the Bruch membrane and retinal pigment epithelium and are shown below. They are also seen in Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada (VKH) syndrome.
  • If untreated, the disease may lead to significant visual loss, so early aggressive corticosteroid therapy is initiated. The best prophylactic measure is enucleation of the injured eye within 10-14 days. It is done in severely injured eyes with no visual potential.

Explanation of other options:

Macular oedema (Option A): It is associated with diabetes and retinal vascular disease and can result in blurred vision. Symptoms in the non-injured eye are typical of a case of sympathetic ophthalmitis.

Optic nerve avulsion (Option C) results in sudden, profound, and permanent visual loss, typically in the traumatised eye, not the contralateral one.

Delayed vitreous haemorrhage (Option D) also affects the traumatised eye and presents with sudden visual obscuration, not difficulty with reading or gradual vision loss.

Explanation:

Vossius ring is classically seen following blunt ocular trauma (concussion injury).

  • A Vossius ring is a circular imprint of pigment on the anterior lens capsule, formed when the iris is compressed against the lens during blunt trauma to the eye. The size of the Vossius ring corresponds to the size of the constricted pupil.
  • The pigment comes from the posterior pigmented epithelium of the iris, and the pattern of the ring corresponds precisely to the size and shape of the constricted pupil at the moment of impact.

Explanation of other options:

Retinal detachment (Option B): It does not involve iris-lens contact, thus it cannot produce a Vossius ring.

Keratoconus (Option C): A non-inflammatory ectatic corneal disorder unrelated to trauma or pigment deposition.

Corneal dystrophy (Option D) refers to a group of inherited corneal diseases affecting the stromal or epithelial layers and does not involve the lens or iris compression.

questions.text: Raccoon eyes are seen in fracture of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Raccoon eyes are most commonly seen in fractures of the anterior cranial fossa.

  • The term "raccoon eyes" or "panda eyes" refers to bilateral periorbital ecchymosis resulting from the tracking of blood from a basal skull fracture, most specifically involving the anterior cranial fossa.
  • The image below shows raccoon/panda eyes.
  • This feature is clinically important as it may be one of the earliest external signs of a serious cranial base injury, and is often associated with CSF rhinorrhea, depending on the extent of the fracture.

Explanation of other options:

Middle cranial fossa (Option B): Fractures of the middle cranial fossa are more commonly associated with hemotympanum, Battle's sign (postauricular ecchymosis), and CSF otorrhea.

The image below shows Battle's sign.

Posterior cranial fossa (Option C): Fractures of the posterior cranial fossa typically affect the occipital bone and cerebellum and are less likely to cause anterior periorbital ecchymosis.

questions.text: True about chemical injury to the eye are all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acid injuries do not cause more severe damage than alkali injuries, making Option A incorrect and therefore the correct answer.

  • In ocular chemical injuries, alkali burns are significantly more dangerous than acid burns. This is because alkalis penetrate deeper into ocular tissues, as they do not coagulate proteins but instead saponify fats and denature proteins, allowing the chemical to reach the deeper structures of the eye.
  • On the other hand, acid injuries typically cause coagulative necrosis, which forms a protective barrier that limits deeper penetration.
  • Immediate and copious irrigation with balanced salt solution, such as Ringer's lactate (Option B is ruled out), is emphasised as the most crucial first step in the treatment of chemical injuries to the eye.
  • Steroids (Option C is ruled out) are used to reduce inflammation, particularly anterior uveitis, though they must be tapered to avoid delayed healing.

Explanation of other options:

Intraocular pressure can be elevated in the initial period (Option D): This is due to trabecular meshwork damage or inflammation, especially in the acute phase of chemical injury.

questions.text: The most common cause of ocular foreign bodies is?
questions.solution:
Explanation: 

The most common cause of intraocular foreign bodies is the use of a chisel and hammer, which projects metallic fragments, especially steel, into the eye.

  • The high velocity impact from the chisel-hammer combination projects metallic fragments into the eye, often penetrating the globe and depositing iron into intraocular tissues. This leads to siderosis bulbi, a toxic condition that damages multiple ocular structures, including the lens, retina, and trabecular meshwork. Clinically, this results in pigmentary changes such as radial iron deposits on the lens capsule (cataract), heterochromia, pigmentary retinopathy, and even secondary glaucoma.
  • ERG in siderosis bulbi shows an attenuation in the b-wave, which reflects the activity of bipolar and Müller cells, indicating ongoing retinal dysfunction and damage due to iron toxicity.
  • The image below shows siderosis bulbi.
  • Another common metal causing metallosis is copper, resulting in chalcosis.
  • When the copper content is high, it may provoke a severe inflammatory reaction resembling endophthalmitis, potentially leading to phthisis bulbi. However, alloys with a lower copper content-such as brass or bronze-typically produce a milder form of chalcosis. In such cases, copper ions are deposited inside the eye, resulting in characteristic findings similar to Wilson's disease.
  • These include a Kayser-Fleischer ring (shown below) at the corneal margin and a 'sunflower' cataract in the anterior lens. Copper can also deposit in the retina as golden plaques observable on ophthalmoscopy. Unlike iron, copper is less toxic to the retina, so degenerative retinopathy is uncommon, and visual function may be preserved.

Explanation of other options:

Glass, plastics, and stone (Options B, C, and D): Can cause ocular trauma, but are not the most common cause of penetrating intraocular foreign bodies.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male suffered eye trauma a day ago. He presented today with a decrease in vision. His retina showed this image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette of recent trauma, followed by reduced visual acuity, is choroidal rupture.

  • Choroidal rupture usually occurs following blunt trauma and is a break in the choroid, Bruch's membrane, and retinal pigment epithelium and can be masked initially by subretinal haemorrhage..
  • As healing progresses and blood reabsorbs, a characteristic crescent-shaped white streak appears concentric to the optic disc, representing exposed sclera due to underlying tissue disruption. If the fovea is involved, visual prognosis is poor.

Explanation of other options:

Angioid streaks (Option A): Bilateral, symmetrical, crack-like dehiscences that are associated with systemic conditions like pseudoxanthoma elasticum and Paget disease. They are not trauma-induced and usually develop gradually over time. It is shown below.

Choroidal neovascular membrane (Option C): It can be seen as an uncommon delayed complication of choroidal rupture.

Retinal detachment (Option D): Since the image shows a subretinal pathology and the retina is intact, this option can be ruled out.

choices.text: Penetrating injury to the ciliary body

questions.solution:
Explanation:

Berlin's oedema is used to refer to commotio retinae involving the posterior pole and occurs after blunt trauma.

  • Berlin's oedema refers to retinal whitening or opacification, particularly affecting the posterior pole and is seen commonly after blunt trauma (Options A, B, C ruled out). Clinically, it may lead to visual disturbances depending on the extent of macular involvement.
  • The image below shows commotio retinae.
  • This phenomenon is part of a broader condition known as commotio retinae. The diagnosis is often confirmed with optical coherence tomography (OCT), which shows hyperreflectivity of the outer retina, and there is currently no specific therapy for the condition.

questions.text: An 18-year-old presented to you with a history of blunt trauma 3 days ago. On examination, the following finding was seen. Intraocular pressure was measured to be 55 mm Hg. What is the best management modality?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows total hyphema - complete filling of the anterior chamber with blood and raised IOP > 50 mm Hg for two days, which is best managed by surgical evacuation.

  • Anterior chamber paracentesis or surgical evacuation is necessary in some cases of hyphema where there is a total hyphema with IOP >50 mmHg for 2 days or IOP >35 mmHg for 5 days.
  • The goal is to prevent complications like permanent corneal staining, optic nerve atrophy, and chronic secondary glaucoma. Medical therapy alone is inadequate in such cases due to the risk of rapid vision loss from elevated pressure and ischemic damage.

Explanation of other options:

Topical latanoprost (Option A): It is used as a management modality to reduce intraocular pressure in the setting of hyphema, but it is not the best management modality in this scenario.

Ephedrine (Option B): Miotics are contraindicated as they may increase the pupillary block and disturb the blood-aqueous barrier.

NSAIDs (Option C): Not used for analgesia due to their anticoagulant properties.

questions.text: Alkali injury to the eye leads to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Alkali injury to the eye causes symblepharon due to conjunctival scarring and adhesion formation.

  • Symblepharon, which is an adhesion between the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva, is a well-known sequela of alkali injury. Alkalis such as ammonia and sodium hydroxide penetrate ocular tissues rapidly, causing extensive necrosis of the conjunctival and corneal epithelium. This leads to loss of limbal stem cells and deep stromal inflammation. As the healing process progresses, fibroblasts and inflammatory cells cause scar formation, resulting in adhesions between ocular surfaces - a condition known as symblepharon.
  • Acid injuries typically cause coagulative necrosis, which forms a protective barrier that limits deeper penetration, in contrast to alkali burns.

Explanation of other options:

Optic neuritis (Option A): It can be ruled out as alkali burns primarily affect anterior segment structures like the cornea and conjunctiva, not the optic nerve.

Globe perforation(Option B): Alkali injuries typically cause chemical burns and tissue necrosis, not mechanical rupture or perforation.

Retinal detachment(Option C): Retinal detachment is more commonly related to trauma or vitreoretinal disorders.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male has presented with complaints of headache. His visual acuity is 6/6. Intraocular pressure is measured to be 24 mmHg in the right eye and 18 mmHg in the left eye. On gonioscopy, the following finding is seen. He also gives a history of trauma on his head and eye in his childhood. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette of raised intraocular pressure in one eye, history of blunt trauma and gonioscopy finding is angle recession glaucoma.

  • Angle recession glaucoma is a secondary open-angle glaucoma resulting from blunt trauma that causes a tear between the longitudinal and circular muscles of the ciliary body, typically visible on gonioscopy as a widened ciliary body face. The increase in intraocular pressure results primarily from damage to the trabecular meshwork, rather than from the angle recession alone.

Explanation for other options:

Hyphema (Option A): It has an acute presentation with blood in the anterior chamber and can be ruled out since the injury occurred years ago.

Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) (Option B): It is not associated with a history of trauma.

Migraine (Option C): Presents with unilateral headache but does not cause increased IOP or angle recession on gonioscopy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male came with a history of a battery bursting on his face an hour ago. Examination findings are as shown below. Which of the following is true about his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct statement about the depicted grade 2 chemical injury is - Steroids should be started.

  • This patient has sustained an ocular chemical injury following a battery explosion, commonly due to acid burns like sulphuric or hydrofluoric acid. Such injuries, especially with visible conjunctival whitening, epithelial damage, or corneal haze, often qualify as Grade 2 or higher based on the Roper-Hall classification.
  • The Roper-Hall grading system categorises acute ocular chemical burns by evaluating the transparency of the cornea and the extent of ischemia at the limbus, as seen by the presence or absence of blood flow in the superficial and deep limbal vessels.
    • Grade 1 includes injuries with a clear cornea, only epithelial damage, and no limbal ischemia, offering an excellent prognosis.
    • Grade 2 shows a hazy cornea with discernible iris details and limbal ischemia involving less than one-third of its circumference, and typically has a good prognosis. (Options A and C ruled out)
    • Grade 3 is marked by total epithelial loss, stromal haze that obscures iris details, and ischemia involving one-third to one-half of the limbus, associated with a guarded prognosis.
    • Grade 4 presents with a completely opaque cornea and ischemia of more than 50% of the limbus, usually indicating a poor visual prognosis.
  • Management of chemical eye injuries depends on the severity of the damage. Initial management consists of copious irrigation. For mild cases (Grades 1 and 2), treatment typically involves the application of topical antibiotic ointment for approximately one week to prevent infection. If needed, topical steroids and cycloplegic agents may also be used to control inflammation and discomfort.
  • In contrast, moderate to severe chemical burns require a more aggressive approach aimed at minimising inflammation, stimulating the regeneration of the corneal epithelium, and preventing the development of corneal ulcers. For these more serious injuries, it is essential to use preservative-free eye drops, which are less irritating and safer for the already compromised ocular surface.
  • Bandaging can trap the chemical agent against the eye, worsening the exposure. Instead, the eye should be kept open for irrigation and topical medications. (Option B ruled out)
  • Surgical modalities include limbal stem cell transplant, tenon advancement flap, and amniotic membrane grafting. In delayed cases, symplepharon division, conjunctival grafting and keratoplasty can be done.

questions.text: A patient presents with diplopia both while looking up and down. Which of the following could be the cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely cause of diplopia in both upgaze and downgaze is a blow-out fracture, due to mechanical entrapment or hemorrhagic oedema affecting the extraocular muscles.

  • Blow-out fractures involve the orbital floor, often leading to entrapment of the inferior rectus or inferior oblique muscles or connective tissue and fat.
  • This entrapment restricts ocular motility, causing diplopia, especially in both upward and downward gaze.
  • Forced duction tests and increased intraocular pressure during eye movement can be used for confirmation.

Explanation for other options:

Conjunctivitis (Option A): A surface inflammation that does not affect ocular motility or extraocular muscles, so it does not cause diplopia.

Corneal opacity (Option B): It usually causes monoocular diplopia but does not vary with gaze.

Sixth nerve palsy (Option C): It causes horizontal diplopia, particularly in lateral gaze due to lateral rectus weakness.

questions.text: All of the following can cause glaucoma after trauma except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Primary angle closure does not occur as a sequela of blunt ocular trauma, making it the correct exception in this question.

  • Trauma-related glaucoma may arise through multiple mechanisms, most of which involve structural damage to the anterior segment.
  • Angle recession occurs due to rupture of the ciliary body face, resulting in trabecular meshwork dysfunction and delayed-onset glaucoma (noted in <10% after 10 years). (Option A ruled out)
  • Ghost cell glaucoma is caused by degenerated red blood cells (ghost cells) entering the anterior chamber. This usually occurs 1- 2 weeks post-vitreal haemorrhage, which can occur after trauma and causes trabecular meshwork blockage and elevated IOP. (Option B ruled out)
  • Hyphema leads to elevated IOP through direct obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by RBCs or secondary haemorrhage (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a history of ocular trauma with a metallic body 3 months ago. Examination of the right eye reveals decreased vision, brownish discolouration of the anterior lens capsule, and a dilated pupil with sluggish reaction. Fundus shows retinal pigmentary changes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is siderosis bulbi, which is caused by intraocular iron particles secondary to trauma.

  • Siderosis bulbi results from prolonged retention of an iron-containing intraocular foreign body. Iron ions deposit in ocular tissues, exerting toxic effects on the lens, retina, and trabecular meshwork.
  • Clinically, this manifests as radial iron deposition on the anterior lens capsule (leading to cataract), heterochromia of the iris, pigmentary retinopathy, and sometimes secondary open-angle glaucoma due to trabecular damage.
  • Electroretinography (ERG) typically shows a progressive reduction in the b-wave amplitude, indicating dysfunction of the inner retinal layers, particularly bipolar and Müller cells, reflecting ongoing retinal toxicity.

Explanation of other options:

Sympathetic ophthalmia (Option A): A bilateral granulomatous uveitis associated with penetrating trauma. It occurs secondary to exposure to uveal antigens released due to injury to the injured eye.

Chalcosis bulbi (Option B): It occurs due to a copper foreign body and presents with sunflower cataracts. If the copper content is high, it can lead to a severe inflammatory reaction resembling endophthalmitis.

Angle recession glaucoma (Option D): Arises due to blunt trauma disrupting the angle structures.

questions.text: Ghost cell glaucoma occurs secondary to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ghost cell glaucoma occurs secondary to vitreous haemorrhage and is a cause of traumatic glaucoma.

  • Ghost cell glaucoma is a type of secondary open-angle glaucoma caused by degenerated red blood cells (ghost cells) that originate after a vitreous haemorrhage. These cells are less pliable and can obstruct the trabecular meshwork, leading to elevated intraocular pressure.
  • The process typically occurs weeks after the initial haemorrhage as the blood breaks down in the vitreous cavity and the ghost cells migrate into the anterior chamber. Their rigid, khaki-colored morphology allows them to lodge in the trabecular meshwork, impeding aqueous outflow and causing glaucoma.
  • Initial management of ghost cell glaucoma involves lowering intraocular pressure using aqueous suppressants.
  • If intraocular pressure remains uncontrolled, irrigation of the anterior chamber is performed to physically remove the obstructing ghost cells. In cases where vitreous haemorrhage persists and continues to supply ghost cells into the anterior chamber, a pars plana vitrectomy may be indicated to eliminate the source of ghost cells and prevent recurrence.

Explanation of other options:

Retinal detachment (Option B): It does not generate ghost cells unless complicated by haemorrhage; it is not a primary cause.

Central Retinal Vein Occlusion/CRVO (Option C): It can lead to neovascular glaucoma.

Iritis (Option D): It is associated with inflammatory or uveitic glaucoma.
